etymologies: mid 19th century: from French automatisme, from automate ‘automaton’, from Greek automatos ‘acting of itself’ (see automaton)late 18th century (with reference to a theory that living organisms act purely mechanically): from automat- (in see automaton) + -ism, and probably partly from French automatisme

definitions: the performance of actions without conscious thought or intention

examples.text: diabetic patients who commit crimes while hypoglycemic may be able to plead automatism

shortDefinitions: performance of actions without conscious thought or intention

definitions: an action performed unconsciously or involuntarily

examples.text: automatisms occurred in all four epileptic syndromes

definitions: the avoidance of conscious intention in producing works of art, especially by using mechanical techniques or subconscious associations.
shortDefinitions: avoidance of conscious intention in producing works of art
